Hi, you want to adjust CPUCore and CPUShare parameters:

```
numcore: 2
coreshare: 2
```

`numcore` should be the number of CPU cores on the machine, `coreshare` the number of containers you want to spawn per core. Effectively you'll get core * share containers in parallel.

So I should put this two lines in this file?
openwhisk/ansible/environments/distributed/group_vars/all

Unfortunately, it's not per env. configurable as of today. You'll need to change in the global group_vars/all.

Feel free to open a PR making this configurable. It would be along these lines:

```
numcore: "{{ invoker_numcore | default(2) }}"
...
```

Thanks. I don't really care if its per environment reconfigurable.
So I just need to change ansible/group_vars/all this file and recompile?

@rabbah , @dubeejw , @mdeuser : @bpoole16 and I will be making a push soon which takes `--limit` and `--skip` flags into account. In the mean time, sorting is currently the default for any listing we do as of this version of Alphabetize. Since this would entail bringing in all items of a particular entity at a given time no matter the size of the actual list to be printed, should we instead make sorting an optional flag? Then users could choose whether items should be sorted or not, and it could relieve some traffic back and forth from the server to the CLI. Thoughts on this?

Me too getting the same error - 
  error: Unable to invoke action 'utils/echo': Post https://172.17.0.1/api/v1/namespaces/whisk.system/actions/utils/echo?blocking=true&result=true: dial tcp 172.17.0.1:443: getsockopt: connection refused.

Could anyone please help me in this.

Maybe don't over complicate this at first. The API call gives you back a response. The cli(ent) sorts that response. Done. 

If this turns out to be confusing then we can revisit. I don't think it's common to list with small limits or have hundreds/thousands of assets in a namespace.

The problem we ran into, and why we originally concluded this was a server issue, was that `--limit` and `--skip` flags would and could return irregular looking lists without having all the data on hand locally. For example: 
```
$ wsk action list
actions
/guest/C
/guest/A
/guest/B
```
This is how a list might look with the current build. `C` is the most recent action, hence being the first item in the list, and `B` being the oldest action. With alphabetize, it's obviously:
```
$ wsk action list
actions
/guest/A
/guest/B
/guest/C
```
Here's the problem that occurs if we include either `--skip` or `--limit`:
```
$ wsk action list --skip 1
actions
/guest/A
/guest/B
```
Notice that `skip` took away the last item, not the first, since `C` was the newest action in the DB and would have been the first item in the list to skip before sorting. 
```
$ wsk action list --limit 2
actions
/guest/A
/guest/C
```
Here, because the limit is 2, but action `B` is outside of that range, it is ignored altogether. Now it looks like `B` doesn't exist. 

These are the issues we were concerned with. And it only gets more complicated when you have larger and larger lists to print (@dubeejw first pointed this out with an example I can grab if you would like to discuss further).  The only way we are aware of to alleviate this issue is to stop the `limit` and `skip` flags from going to the server, grab all the data (however much that may be) for the list, sort the list, then implement the flags locally to our newly sorted list before printing.

right now, the cli's current default page limit is 30 which may be exceeded today by some customer environments.   just guessing, but at some point i think we'll start seeing tooling-generated actions and triggers which may bump up the average entities/namespace counts.  in either case, when providing a sorted list, i think we all agree that the expectation is that the current page is sorted wrt to the entire entity list, not just a subset

I understand the issue Brandon - but before we do something more complicated let's just do the simple thing first. Hence my point: don't over complicate it.

The API currently is what it is and it's still useful to sort action alphabetically. A user who wants to see more than 30 actions can bump the limit to 200. In that list the cli should show the result alphabetically. I don't think users will shrink the list but rather expand it.

Just like in a shell you have ls and ls -t both are desired. The canonical ordering today is by time because it's uniform for all assets. 

I can envision that activations are sorted by time and everything else by name. This will require several backend changes as I pointed out.
@mdeuser @csantanapr Is the consensus that we should replace existing functionality or implement the `--stdout` along side of existing functionality?
replace - but need to make sure there's doc somewhere to describe this behavior change.. certainly in the command help
the cli has two flags: verbose and debug right? how about verbose truncate and debug doesn't.

@underwoodb-sd-ibm - after talking with carlos, i think this is the final design for this issue
- sort only on the request block of entities
- by default, do not sort.  leave the list obtain from the backend as-is
- add a sort alpha flag.  in the help description, be sure to mention this is only applicable within the limit/skip returned block

```
@RunWith(classOf[JUnitRunner])
class AuthenticatedRouteTests
```

For original codes, it doesn't add `@RunWith(classOf[JUnitRunner])` on this class, 
If doesn't add, it will don't run the test case for this class.
So i added to support running these test cases for this class

Just discussed with my old team.

Their initial decision to externalize the reference names as the actual strings was due to the misunderstanding that that was a requirement for translation to work properly. A new team has since taken over that project and made the decision to use shortened names.

I was given this as a reference for bluemix CLI guidelines:
https://github.com/IBM-Bluemix/bluemix-cli-sdk/blob/master/docs/plugin_developer_guide.md#6-globalization

and while their example shows the ```id``` and ```translation``` as the same, it's important to note that this is their single example, not a hard requirement. If we take a look at the actual 3rd party translation library documentation (https://github.com/nicksnyder/go-i18n#workflow) you see another style of shortened reference names. 

Knowing what freedoms we have now, I think we absolutely should shorten these references with our own style or an existing one, especially as an open-sourced project.
not merged
@drcariel -  thanks for digging into the current best practices. I agree we can move away from having the resource key match the actual text.
yes it is badly needed.

I wonder if the documentation for how to set up the client based authentication belongs in the same place our docs talk about ssl certificates in general - so that the CLI doc is strictly about the CLI not a deployment.

```  
I wonder if the documentation for how to set up the client based authentication 
belongs in the same place our docs talk about ssl certificates in general 
- so that the CLI doc is strictly about the CLI not a deployment.
```
Answer: openwhisk itself doens't care how to generate client certificate(genssh.sh just an example), it just provide a entry point configuration to how to use it, so openwhisk users(for example:a company) just configure `nginx.ssl.client_ca_cert` to `their own client ca path`,  and create every client certificate(cert/key) for its employees.

So employee can download its own client certificate(cert/key) from somewhere(may be download url),
and use `wsk -i property set --cert <cert> --key <key> XXX` can access openwhisk env.

So i will improve the docs.
When authenticating with just the cert, can the namespace property value still be "_"?  Possibly related to a discussion thread above..
What is the expected behavior when both the authkey and cert property values are set?
what about this one: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/9401f8b29ae2ddc470d9e543f0f790776ae0b028/ansible/group_vars/all#L163
@starpit can you review please?

In general: Try to bury all implementation details in the interface, for instance: We cast all the BigInts to Int outside of the replication? Then do the cast as part of the interface.

Returning a String and "casting" it to a UUID is another example. Just cast inside the interface.

That keeps the clients clean.

About the documentation in cli.md: the point is that for the CLI point of view, the user needs to know 1 command. The rest of the text is talking about configuring the deployment. I don't think this is the best place for it. There's another doc where there's discussion of certificates.
I labeled this a "WIP" patch per the description. Thanks @ddragosd for raising these early. I expect this PR is going to involve a bit more.
